column4: Please run this script: http://sourceforge.net/projects/bootinfoscript/ and pastebin the output.
The issue isn't with the grub config?
Oh, I misunderstood that script - what is it exactly you hope this script will tell me

It will tell me a lot of things. What drives /partitions you have, what bootloaders are installed to each of these, is grub installed such that it is looking in the correct partitions for its files, etc.
Grub works ok, it just takes half an hour to do it
So that information is surely useless?
If it's grub 1.97 beta4 (from karmic), rather than 1.98 from lucid, and you have grub installed to the mbr of a drive different than the one that contains /boot, that would explain the delay.
I have 1.98 (from 10.4 server) I think, and there is only one drive
It was a fresh install, no special options (other than ubuntu desktop), only one hard drive installed. I had the issue on another machine as well....
Possibly, I don't recall, I just used Guided LVM (whole disk)

If /boot is on LVM then you won't be able to use grub legacy at all. Are you sure that it's grub that is being slow? By default in Ubuntu the grub menu isn't even shown, so there is no way to tell when grub has finished and you're into the linux kernel / init.
Last time I had this issue, I was informed there was an issue with some grub2 installs where grub stalled for an indeterminate amount of time
As thats on a server that is on 24/7, it isn't so much of an issue.
That issue was very specific, only occuring with karmic, and only when grub's mbr portion was on a different drive than /boot.
Ok, I'm going to leave it for this evening and re-download ubuntu (desktop this time) and install without LVM tomorrow, and see what happens.
